title: 115_s1072
content:
The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans under certain conditions. Services covered may include care for a dependent while the homeless veteran receives services from a grant recipient. Partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Section 2022A of Title 38, United States Code, authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary can fund general legal services for these individuals through these partnerships, subject to the availability of funds. The Secretary ensures partnerships for legal services are distributed equitably across the US, including rural areas, tribal lands, Native Americans, and tribal organizations. Legal services address the needs of homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk include housing, family law, income support, and criminal defense. The legal services provided for homeless veterans and those at risk include defense for issues related to homelessness, such as outstanding warrants and driver's license revocation, to help reduce recidivism and overcome reentry obstacles in employment or housing. The Secretary may also consider other necessary legal services and consult with public and private entities for assistance in identifying and coordinating outreach relationships with relevant organizations. The Secretary may require periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness through partnerships with organizations. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The Department of Veterans Affairs expands its authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans who meet specific eligibility criteria under section 2062 of title 38, United States Code. Eligible veterans must be enrolled for care and receiving assistance under the United States Housing Act of 1937 or care in a domiciliary setting for 60 consecutive days. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide dental care to homeless veterans who meet eligibility criteria, including being enrolled for care and receiving assistance under specific programs for 60 consecutive days. This includes therapeutic residence, community residential care, and settings funded by the Secretary. The Secretary may disregard breaks in assistance or care for which the veteran is not responsible. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by striking subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. In section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code, amendments are made for fiscal year 2017 funding. Additionally, training entities for supportive services are extended through 2017. A requirement is set for the Comptroller General to study VA homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, which required annual reports on assistance to homeless veterans, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of the same title is updated accordingly.
